item.title: Downloads
item.description: Manual Download You can always get the latest static version of Module.sh from: https://mdl.sh/latest Just download it and save it as module.sh. To use Module.sh in your script you have to source it like that: . ./module.sh If you want to load it relative to your script and not relative to your current work directory you can use something like: . "$(dirname "$(readlink -f "$0")")/module.sh" Dynamic Script If you want to let your script download the latest version of Module.

item.title: Reasons
item.description: Scope When your Scripts become larger you often struggle with the fact that every variable name is part of the global scope (even the ones within functions). An easy fix is to use the local keyword. But did you know that local is not POSIX compliant? Module.sh solves the issue by isolating every module within its own Sub-Shell. That way you can keep using global variable names, as global gets limited to your module.
